title: Covered Interest Parity
notes: This equation defines covered interest parity. F represents the forward exchange rate
column5: S is the spot exchange rate
column6: r_domestic is the domestic interest rate
column7: and r_foreign is the foreign interest rate. CIP must hold to prevent arbitrage opportunities in the foreign exchange market.

title: Uncovered Interest Parity
notes: This equation defines uncovered interest parity. E[F] represents the expected future spot rate
column5: S is the current spot rate
column6: r_domestic is the domestic interest rate
column7: and r_foreign is the foreign interest rate. UIP is a theoretical condition that often does not hold in practice.

title: Forward Premium
notes: This equation calculates the forward premium or discount. Forward Premium represents the percentage difference between forward and spot rates. Positive values indicate the domestic currency is trading at a forward premium (stronger forward than spot).

title: Forward Discount
notes: This equation calculates the forward discount. Forward Discount represents the percentage by which the forward rate is below the spot rate. A forward discount indicates the domestic currency is expected to weaken.

title: Continuous Covered Parity
notes: This equation defines covered interest parity with continuous compounding. F represents the forward rate
column5: S is the spot rate
column6: r_domestic and r_foreign are continuously compounded interest rates
column7: and T is time to maturity. This form is widely used in derivatives pricing.

title: Forward Rate Agreement Value
main_category: Currency and FX - Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation calculates the value of a Forward Rate Agreement. V_FRA represents the mark-to-market value
column5: N is the notional
column6: L is the realized LIBOR rate
column7: K is the agreed FRA rate
column8: delta is the day count fraction
column9: and DF is the discount factor.

title: Forward Rate Agreement Rate
equation_latex: FRA Rate = ((1 + r_long * T_long) / (1 + r_short * T_short) - 1) * (360 / delta)
main_category: Currency and FX - Interest Rate Parity
notes: This equation calculates the FRA rate. FRA Rate represents the rate agreed in the FRA contract
column5: r_long is the rate for the longer period
column6: r_short is the rate for the shorter period
column7: T_long and T_short are the year fractions
column8: and delta is the day count in days.

title: Purchasing Power Parity (Absolute)
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines absolute purchasing power parity. S represents the exchange rate that equalizes the purchasing power of two currencies
column5: P_domestic is the domestic price level
column6: and P_foreign is the foreign price level. This is the law of one price applied to price levels.

title: Purchasing Power Parity (Relative)
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines relative purchasing power parity. S_1/S_0 represents the change in the exchange rate
column5: inflation_domestic is the domestic inflation rate
column6: and inflation_foreign is the foreign inflation rate. This predicts how exchange rates adjust for inflation differentials.

title: Real Exchange Rate
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation calculates the real exchange rate. RER represents the relative price of goods across countries
column5: S is the nominal exchange rate
column6: P_foreign is the foreign price level
column7: and P_domestic is the domestic price level. RER deviations from 1 indicate real exchange rate misalignment.

title: Big Mac Index
equation_latex: Big Mac PPP = Local Price / US Price
main_category: Currency and FX - Purchasing Power Parity
notes: This equation defines the Big Mac index methodology. Big Mac PPP represents the implied exchange rate based on Big Mac prices
column5: Local Price is the Big Mac price in local currency
column6: and US Price is the Big Mac price in the US. This provides a simple PPP benchmark.

title: FX Forward Valuation
notes: This equation calculates the value of an FX forward. V_forward represents the mark-to-market value
column5: F_market is the market forward rate
column6: F_theoretical is the contract forward rate
column8: and DF is the discount factor.

title: Cross Rate
notes: This equation calculates a cross exchange rate. S_cross represents the exchange rate between currencies A and B
column5: S_A/USD is the rate between A and USD
column6: and S_B/USD is the rate between B and USD. Cross rates are derived from rates against a common currency.

title: Triangular Arbitrage
notes: This equation defines the no-arbitrage condition for triangular arbitrage. S_A/B represents the direct rate
column5: S_A/USD and S_USD/B are cross rates through USD. Any arbitrage opportunities that deviation creates should be quickly eliminated.

title: Currency Option Delta (Call)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a currency call option. Delta_C represents the sensitivity to the spot rate
column5: q is the foreign risk-free rate
column6: T is time to expiration
column7: and N(d_1) is the cumulative normal distribution. Foreign currency options use the Garman-Kohlhagen model.

title: Currency Option Delta (Put)
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a currency put option. Delta_P represents the sensitivity to the spot rate
column5: q is the foreign risk-free rate
column6: T is time to expiration
column7: and N(-d_1) is the cumulative normal. Put delta is negative
column8: as put prices fall when the currency appreciates.

title: Garman-Kohlhagen Call Price
notes: This equation prices a European currency call option using the Garman-Kohlhagen model. C represents the call price
column5: r_d is the domestic rate
column6: F is the forward rate
column8: and N(d) are cumulative normal distributions. This extends Black-Scholes for two currencies.

title: Garman-Kohlhagen d_1
notes: This equation defines d_1 for the Garman-Kohlhagen model. d_1 combines the moneyness (ln(F/K))
column5: volatility sigma
column6: and time to expiration T. This parameter is used in both the call and put pricing formulas.

title: Currency Put-Call Parity
equation_latex: C + K * e^{-r_d T} = P + F * e^{-q T}
notes: This equation defines put-call parity for currency options. C and P are call and put prices
column5: K is the strike
column6: r_d is the domestic rate
column8: and F is the forward rate. This no-arbitrage relationship links call and put prices.

title: Carry Trade Return
notes: This equation calculates the expected return from a carry trade. R_carry represents the expected return from borrowing in low-yield currencies and investing in high-yield currencies
column5: r_foreign and r_domestic are interest rates
column6: and the last term is expected depreciation.

title: Carry Trade Sharpe Ratio
equation_latex: Sharpe = (r_foreign - r_domestic - sigma_S * sigma_R * rho) / sigma_carry
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio for carry trades. Sharpe represents risk-adjusted carry return
column5: r_foreign - r_domestic is the interest rate differential
column6: sigma_S is spot volatility

title: FX Swap Points
equation_latex: Swap Points = F - S = S * (r_d - r_f) * T
notes: This equation calculates the swap points for an FX swap. Swap Points represent the difference between forward and spot rates
column5: which approximately equals the interest rate differential times the spot rate and time to maturity.

title: FX Implied Volatility
notes: This equation relates implied to realized volatility for currency pairs. sigma_implied represents the volatility implied by option prices
column5: sigma_realized is historical volatility
column6: and rho is the correlation between spot returns and volatility. Implied volatility is typically higher for currencies.

title: Currency Basis
main_category: Currency and FX - Cross Currency Swaps
notes: This equation calculates the currency basis in cross-currency swaps. Currency Basis represents the deviation from covered interest parity
column5: F_market is the market forward rate
column6: and F_CIP is the CIP-implied forward. A positive basis indicates funding pressure in the foreign currency.

title: Cross Currency Swap Spread
equation_latex: CCS Spread = R_domestic - R_foreign - (S_0 - F_CIP) / S_0
main_category: Currency and FX - Cross Currency Swaps
notes: This equation calculates the cross-currency swap spread. CCS Spread represents the differential between domestic and foreign rates adjusted for the forward points
column5: R_domestic and R_foreign are rates
column6: S_0 is spot
column7: and F_CIP is the CIP forward.

title: FX Risk Reversal
equation_latex: Risk Reversal = Call Vol - Put Vol
notes: This equation calculates the FX risk reversal. Risk Reversal represents the volatility difference between out-of-the-money calls and puts
column5: which indicates market skew. Positive risk reversal means calls are more expensive (market expects currency appreciation).

title: FX Butterfly
equation_latex: Butterfly = (AtM Vol + 25D Call Vol + 25D Put Vol) / 3 - AtM Vol
notes: This equation calculates the FX butterfly spread. Butterfly represents the curvature of the volatility smile
column5: AtM Vol is at-the-money volatility
column6: and 25D Call/Put are 25-delta option volatilities. This measures the smile curvature.

title: FX Delta Neutral Straddle
notes: This equation describes a delta-neutral straddle using 25-delta options. Straddle represents buying equal amounts of 25-delta calls and puts to create a position that profits from volatility regardless of direction. This is a common volatility trading strategy.

title: NDF Valuation
notes: This equation calculates the value of a Non-Deliverable Forward. V_NDF represents the mark-to-market value
column5: N is the notional in USD
column6: S_market is the current NDF rate
column8: and DF_domestic is the domestic discount factor. NDFs are settled in USD.

title: FX Delta Exposure
equation_latex: Delta Exposure = Position Size * Delta * S_0
notes: This equation calculates the delta exposure in FX. Delta Exposure represents the equivalent spot position
column5: Position Size is the option notional
column6: Delta is the option delta
column7: and S_0 is the spot rate. This is used for hedging and risk management.
